An education record is any record which:

  • contains "personally identifiable information" of a student AND

  • is maintained by an educational institution or by a party acting for the institution

Personally Identifiable Information is the kind of information or data from which the identity of a specific person can be determined. For example:

  • student's name

  • student's address

  • social security number

  • student number

  • date of birth

  • place of birth

  • mother’s maiden name

The following are NOT considered part of education records and are therefore NOT subject to the privacy protections of FERPA:

  • Sole Possession Records

  • Law Enforcement Records

  • Employment Records

  • Medical / Treatment Records

  • Alumni Records

  • Unrecorded Grades

[CAMPUSCLUE]As a member of the college community, you may create your own private notes about students in order to help you remember details about your students.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • Sole possession records are defined as records (notes maintained by a faculty member) kept in the sole possession of the [TERM maker]the person who created the record[/TERM] exclusively for the purpose of jogging the maker's memory.

  • These records are not accessible or reviewed by any other person except a [TERM temporary substitute]Someone who temporarily takes the place of the person who created the record[/TERM].

  • Sole possession records are not part of a student's education record. However, once the contents of a sole possession record are disclosed to any party other than a temporary substitute, the record becomes an education record and is protected under FERPA.

[CAMPUSCLUE]If your school shares part of a student's record with a law enforcement unit, that record is still considered an "education record" and is therefore protected under FERPA.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • Records maintained and stored by [TERM law enforcement]any law enforcement unit or campus security[/TERM] for law enforcement purposes

  • Law enforcement may refuse to allow access to these records without students' consent

• Records relating to employees of the institution are excluded from education records.

  • If the employment records are pertaining to a position that only students can fill (e.g. work-study, graduate teaching assistants, etc.) then these records ARE considered part of the student's education record and are therefore protected under FERPA.

[NOTE]Find out if being a lab aide is another example of protected employment records[/NOTE]
These records are made, maintained, and used only in connection with treatment of the student by a [TERM recognized medical professional]physician, psychiatrist, or other medical professional[/TERM].

• Records CREATED AFTER the student has graduated

  • If these records relate to a period when a person was a student, they would then be covered under FERPA.


[CASESTUDY Tom graduated from his university many years ago. Since graduating, he has been very involved as an alumnus. A journalist wants to write a story about his involvement at the university, both as a student and as an alumnus. According to FERPA, what information can be released?]Alumni records are generally open to the public because they are not "education records" under FERPA. However, that does not mean that Tom’s education records (information from when he was a student) is releasable. Unless Tom provides written consent, only directory information from when he was a student can be disclosed.[/CASESTUDY]

  • Instructors are allowed to have students grade each other's work and publicly announce the student's grade for the instructor to record since at the time of the vocalization, the grades were not considered education records.

  • Once the grades have been recorded and maintained by the instructor, these records become part of the student's education record.
